Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: I move: That this bill be now read a second time. This bill makes minor and technical amendments to the Copyright Act 1968 and the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act 2004-that is, the US FTA Implementation Act-to improve Australia's implementation of its copyright obligations under the Australia-United States free trade agreement, hereafter referred to as ‘the agreement'. It is worth recalling that the copyright provisions in the US FTA Implementation Act were very extensive and covered a number of important areas of reform such as giving performers, for the first time, economic and moral rights in sound recordings and broadening criminal offences to target commercial copyright piracy. These important reforms reinforced Australia's reputation as a country which responds to the challenges of the digital age with international best practice copyright laws. However, there are some areas where the copyright amendments could be made clearer. This clarity is important to both international and domestic stakeholders that need certainty about the operation of Australia's copyright laws when they are trading in Australia. Over recent months there has been a series of fruitful discussions between the government, domestic stakeholders and the United States government about the operation of certain amendments made to Australia's copyright laws in the US FTA Implementation Act. I want to emphasise that the government is very clear that it has implemented all of its obligations under the agreement. I also want to make it clear that the agreement has not been changed. However, I do see merit in making some minor and technical amendments to improve the operation and practical effect of the new copyright provisions. I wish to emphasise that the vast majority of stakeholders are in favour of urgent passage and commencement of the bill. Although there have been some concerns raised about the carriage service provider liability provisions in the bill, we believe the amendments as currently drafted implement the obligations under the agreement and will work in practice. I would like to address some of the concerns raised in relation to a carriage service provider's obligation in items 11 and 13 to act to take down material if it ‘becomes aware of facts or circumstances that make it apparent that the copyright material is likely to be infringing' as a condition to taking advantage of the safe harbour provisions. These provisions implement article 17.11.29(b)(v)(B) of the agreement. This article provides that the safe harbour is conditional on a service provider ‘expeditiously removing or disabling access to material residing on its system or network on obtaining actual knowledge of the infringement or becoming aware of facts or circumstances from which the infringement was apparent …' I want to make it clear that the intention of these provisions is to deal with genuine copyright infringements in the online environment. It is not the government's intention that a carriage service provider wanting to take advantage of the safe harbour scheme will have to disable or remove material, or access to material, merely because it becomes aware of an allegation or claim of copyright infringement. Likewise, becoming aware of a court action where there is a claim of copyright infringement will not, in itself, require a carriage service provider seeking to use the safe harbour to take down material. The intention of the government is that a carriage service provider seeking the benefit of the safe harbour will only have to remove material when it is apparent, on the face of the facts and the circumstances known to the service provider, that material will probably, as opposed to possibly, infringe Australia's copyright law. For example, a carriage service provider might become aware of a copy of the latest Harry Potter movie at a site on its network before it has been publicly released in the cinema. As is currently the case, carriage service providers will not be required to actively monitor their systems or networks for such material. Nor will they be required to make independent investigations once they become aware of potential copyright infringement. The probable infringement has to be apparent. The government has consulted domestic stakeholders on the draft bill and has outlined the amendments to the United States government. This consultation process involved a positive exchange of views. The government is also consulting with appropriate stakeholders on the regulations containing details of the safe harbour scheme to address other concerns raised by the carriage service providers. The government believes that these amendments in the bill will clarify the practical effect of the copyright amendments made in the US FTA Implementation Act and continue the ongoing improvement of Australia's copyright laws. I commend the bill to the House and seek speedy passage. I present the explanatory memorandum. Leave granted for second reading debate to continue immediately.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: The Copyright Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 deals with Australia's copyright laws as a direct consequence of arrangements entered into by the government under the US free trade agreement-an FTA in which the details were obviously not properly finalised, and that is the reason we have this legislation before us today. The government says that the bill makes various minor and clarifying amendments to the Copyright Act. This, in our view, is not the case. The amendments are not minor or clarifying; they are detailed and complex, with potentially wide ramifications. They have important new implications, not so much for copyright owners but for the disseminators of copyright material-in particular Internet service providers, referred to as ISPs. With the rapid advance of technology and the high uptake of the Internet in Australia, this has major ramifications for the free and unimpeded flow of information. In the information age, we have to encourage that dissemination of information. We have to facilitate it because we do not want barriers established to prevent that free flow of information. It is essential that we get this right if we are to become a knowledge nation. So, far from being minor and clarifying, this legislation in fact simply highlights another failure of the government to get the detail right in the US free trade agreement. The government has had the best part of two years in developing and negotiating this agreement, and yet it is still making changes to our laws to meet our obligations. It is hoped that this bill will be the last of it. It is true that Labor did have concerns with the US free trade agreement, and we also have concerns with this legislation. Labor was prepared to play a constructive role in relation to the US free trade agreement. However, Labor's offers to work with the government were rejected. The government did itself and the FTA a great disservice by the secret nature of the negotiations. The lack of transparency and consultation created unnecessary problems, resulting in a flawed FTA. The FTA should have been comprehensive. It should not have had a carve-out for sugar. The long phase-in for tariff cuts on beef, dairy and other agricultural products are further obvious deficiencies. The increasingly restrictive arrangements the minister agreed to with regard to intellectual property are another concern. In its initial form, the FTA threatened Australia's Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and local content on television. Labor amended the free trade agreement legislation not only to strengthen the agreement but to protect the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and local content. The government accepted those amendments. This was a demonstration of the constructive role Labor was prepared to play when given the opportunity. It showed clearly that the agreement itself could be strengthened. We still believe the FTA should have been a better agreement. There should have been no carve-out for sugar, as I indicated before. The FTA should have contained a most favoured nation provision in relation to agriculture. It should not have extended copyright in Australian by 20 years. These proposals from Labor were not accepted by the government. It is hoped, in the context of all these problems, that the government does not make the same mistakes if it goes down the path of negotiating a free trade agreement with China. It is to be hoped that in the scoping study that the government is now involved in-and if that leads to further free trade negotiations next year-the government will be more consultative, more transparent and more forthcoming with the detail to ensure that the Australian public is fully capable of understanding what may be in any agreement. Labor did not negotiate the US free trade agreement, but we did support it in the parliament in August. But we are now back again to amend Australia's copyright laws because the government failed to get the detail right. When Labor amended the free trade agreement to protect the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and to protect local content, the government-the Prime Minister in particular-said that Labor were trying to sink the deal, that our proposals were inconsistent with the free trade agreement. It is now quite clear that the hold-up in the free trade agreement had nothing to do with Labor's amendments. They did not sink the deal. Rather, it was the government's failure to correctly legislate to give effect to Australia's obligations that threatened the free trade agreement. Labor's preferred approach to advancing this nation's trade objectives is through the World Trade Organisation, the WTO, and the multilateral round of trade negotiations. We also believe that this can be enhanced in concert with regional forums such as APEC. The gains through the WTO and, regionally, through APEC will be much greater than anything that can be obtained at a merely bilateral level. With the finalisation of the US free trade agreement, it is now imperative that the government recommit its resources and efforts to achieving a successful conclusion to the WTO Doha Round. It is well known that the government was negligent in its responsibilities in allowing the Cairns Group to fracture and diminish in importance, giving rise to the G20 group of countries. Whilst Labor welcomes the formation of the G20, I ask the minister to recommit his effort as chair of the Cairns Group to ensure it contributes to a successful outcome on agriculture in the Doha negotiations, because a successful outcome on agriculture is essential if the Cairns Group is to remain a relevant, cohesive and functional organisation capable of contributing to future WTO rounds that will inevitably address new, challenging and complex areas in trade policy. With regard to copyright issues it is apparent that the US knew what it wanted and bargained hard for the extension of Australia's copyright protection from 50 years to 70 years from the death of the author. The government has admitted that this was its biggest concession to the United States-a big concession with no apparent logic or analysis to support this change in Australian policy. It a change that, according to a group of eminent economists-including Milton Friedman-will result in a financial return of no more than a few extra cents for copyright owners, whereas the restrictions on the flow of information that will result could deny access to useful material to millions of potential users. It is important to protect the interests of copyright owners-Labor accepts that-but it is also important to do it in a way to ensure we do have a free flow of information across the Internet as we develop our knowledge economy. So we have to get the right balance between copyright owners, users and facilitators of information, such as ISPs. The government failed in its duties to get the balance right by agreeing to extend the term of copyright by 20 years. In light of this significant concession, it would have been reasonable to expect Australia to get something significant in return. That is not the case. This bill now poses new problems for Australian copyright interests. Items 11 and 13 of the bill address the copyright obligations of Internet service providers. Unfortunately, the government has not learnt from its previous mistakes with the FTA. Items 11 and 13 appeared without consultation with the Internet industry and came as a complete surprise. Labor was concerned about these new items in their own right. We did not see this, however, as another opportunity to hold up the free trade agreement. Rather, the legitimate concerns of copyright stakeholders had to be addressed. Following the introduction of this legislation into the Senate on Tuesday last week, I met with the Internet Industry Association of Australia on 2 December to discuss the amendments. Later that afternoon, I raised my concerns directly with Minister Vaile here in the House, and I wrote to him on the is same day setting out those concerns in detail. In particular, those concerns go to the potential of these amendments to shift the balance of Australia's copyright interests. They have introduced some new checks to our copyright laws that could undermine the balance. They have created new areas of uncertainty for ISPs in regard to their potential liability arising from alleged copyright breaches. They also have the potential to remove important protections for ISPs' customers, denying them the right to prevent their legitimate material from being taken down. In light of these concerns, on Monday this week Labor referred the bill to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for examination, to give stakeholders the opportunity to have their say on the bill. While the technicalities of this bill can be debated, it is apparent that the government has committed, with the US, to implementing the bill as is-leaving no scope for amendments to clarify the situation. Officials have advised that the concerns raised by ISPs would be addressed by accompanying regulations. However, those regulations have not been made available to us for examination. The House is once again being put into the position of assessing legislation without ing the detail of accompanying regulations that will affect the operation and the impact of the legislation. On 7 December, I received a letter from Minister Vaile responding to the concerns I raised in my letter to him. I have checked with the minister and I seek leave to table these two items of correspondence. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: Notwithstanding the inadequacy of the arrangements outlined in his letter, Labor accepts the minister's assurance that the concerns of ISPs and copyright users arising from these amendments will be resolved through regulations. The minister has made it quite clear that those regulations flesh out the legislative safe harbour provisions and the rights and obligations of copyright owners, users and ISPs. Labor also takes assurance from the minister's commitment that: ... the Government will keep implementation of the scheme under close review and, as necessary will consult with stakeholders on any issues that may arise, including appropriate responses. Labor will keep the government to its commitment to resolve the concerns of ISPs and copyright users in accompanying regulations. ISPs and copyright users must monitor the implementation of this scheme closely and promptly report any problems that arise to the government. In our view, this is not an ideal outcome, but given the minimal time that parliament has had to scrutinise these bills and Australia's commitments under the FTA-due to commence on 1 January-it is the only way that we can proceed at this point. The exchange of diplomatic notes between Australia and the US on 18 November was the final step for our two countries to bring the FTA into force on 1 January next year. On 24 November, I wrote to Minister Vaile seeking a copy of those letters to ascersee- tain what the government had committed to. I seek leave to also table a copy of that correspondence. Leave granted.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: I thank the minister and the House. The Australia-US letters were finally released last Friday, 3 December-10 days after they were exchanged. The contents of those letters are very instructive for the references they make to key areas of Australian public policy. The government has made further commitments to the US on key areas of public policy without any consultation with Australian stakeholders. Notwithstanding Labor's rock-solid legal advice will that our amendments to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme are compliant with both the text of the free trade agreement and with our obligations under the World Trade Organisation TRIPS agreement, the US expressed concerns in its letter. Labor's amendments to protect the PBS were developed on the basis of sound legal advice. It was released publicly. It was fully scrutinised and supported by accompanying legal counsel advice. The government has produced no legal advice to counter it or to contradict it, and neither has the United States. As I said earlier, the government supported Labor's amendments. Therefore, I call on the government to recommit to those amendments and to push back on any US attempts to challenge those amendments in the future. Without any consultation with stakeholders or parliament, the government has committed to review Australia's domestic policy relating to the criminalisation of all forms of satellite signal piracy. This will include unauthorised distribution or receipt of signals by commercial establishments and within the home, and shall conclude no later than 1 July 2005. Australian law is based on the view that copyright breaches or piracy of pay TV that occurs in the home should be subject to civil, not criminal, penalties. We do not want to be in a position where teenagers can be subject to jail terms for this type of activity. Such a penalty would be excessive. For these reasons, Labor calls on the government to restate its view that Australia has a different approach to the US on the criminalisation of pirated satellite signals in the home, and to give an explanation of its commitment to the US to undertake a review of our penalties in this area. We want to know what it has committed to in this regard. So you can see there are a lot of issues that we still have concerns about. It is for that reason that Labor is moving a second reading amendment to this bill. It is particularly in the light of the government's continued failure to get the detail right on the FTA as well as those issues that I have outlined. Accordingly, I move: That all words after ‘That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: ‘whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House: (1) notes: (a) with concern, the failure of the Government to previously correctly implement its obligations under the United States Free Trade Agreement Implementation (USFTAI) Act; (b) with concern, that this Bill has the potential to enable persons other than copyright owners or exclusive licencees to force an internet service provider to take down allegedly infringing copyright material from their system and that this potential new ground for ISP liability is not contained in the USFTAI Act; (c) that this Bill was sent to the Legal and Constitutional Committee which heard evidence that the Bill may disrupt the balance of interests between copyright owners, users and internet service providers; (d) that the Government intends to respond to these concerns through Regulations that will flesh out legislative safe harbour provisions and will consult with stakeholders in the preparation of these provisions; (e) the commitment by the Government to keep implementation of the safe harbour scheme under close review and, as necessary, consult with stakeholders on any issues that may arise, including appropriate responses; (f) that Labor's amendments to the Australia-US FTA are not contrary to the terms of the FTA, our international obligations under WTO TRIPs and are not referred to in this Bill; (g) with concern, that the diplomatic note of exchange from the US refers to Labor's amendments and the House of Representatives therefore calls on the Government not to weaken in response to US pressure and to reaffirm its commitment to Labor's amendments to protect the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and local Australian content for television; and (2) calls on the Government to restate its view that Australia has a different approach to the US on the criminalisation of pirated satellite signals in the home and to therefore give an explanation of its commitment to the US to undertake a review of Australia's domestic policy relating to criminalisation of all of satellite signal piracy, including unauthorstrengthened ised distribution or receipt of signals by commercial establishments and within the home, that shall conclude no later than 1 July 2005'. We believe that there are a number of concerns. We accept in good faith the commitments that have been given by the minister in his correspondence and in the discussions that the government has had with the ISPs. Labor has also had those discussions and will be continuing to monitor them. I say in conclusion that Labor does support the US free trade agreement now that it has been strengthened by Labor's amendment. We have our concerns about these other amendments to the copyright legislation but believe the most sensible thing to do in these circumstances is to put our concerns on the record, monitor the outcome and bring to conclusion the implementation of the free trade agreement between us and the United States.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: Is the amendment seconded? Ms Roxon-I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Hotham has moved as an amendment that all words after ‘That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: I think all of us were interested to hear the member for Hotham say that the Australian Labor Party now endorses the Australia-US free trade agreement. Mr Crean-We strengthened it.

Speaker: Mr SLIPPER
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: To endorse the AustraliaUS free trade agreement is a very sensible position for them to take, even if belatedly. forms The member opposite interjects that they it. The amendments which were made by the Australian Labor Party were not in our view necessary; however, because the free trade agreement was so important to Australia we were prepared to wear those amendments as the price of making sure that the very many benefits that will flow through to the Australia economy as a result of the implementation of the free trade agreement from 1 January next year will occur as quickly as possible. The Copyright Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 will amend the Copyright Act 1968 and the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act 2004. The bill has been prepared in response to ongoing concerns of the US government and some industry stakeholders about the implementation of some of the copyright obligations of the Australia-US free trade agreement in the US free trade agreement act. The member for Hotham has moved a second reading amendment, and it will not come as any surprise to him to know that the government is not prepared to accept that. In fact, given the exchange of correspondence which has taken place recently between the minister and the opposition, one wonders why, other than for the reason of cheap political point scoring, the opposition is moving this pious second reading amendment at all. In his letter to the opposition, the Minister for Trade pointed out that some details, such as when Internet providers are required to block web sites which allegedly breached another person's copyright, could be clarified by a special regulation. This has secured the opposition's general support for the final bills that will implement the free trade agreement. I think it is regrettable that the second reading amendment has been moved but it is heartening that the opposition has been prepared to support the bills in the other place and it is good to see that the opposition does not want the bill currently before the House denied a second reading. With regard to the amendments moved by the member for Hotham in the debate on the second reading, I would like to place a few facts on the parliamentary record. The implementing legislation passed by the parliament in August, prior to the election in which Labor was so comprehensively defeated, was fully consistent with our obligations under the Australia-US free trade agreement. However, the legislation amended the detail of some extremely technical aspects of Australia's copyright law in particular and, by necessity, did so without exposure drafts and without the benefit of extensive consultation with practitioners. Once concerns were raised with the government that some technical aspects of the legislation either had unintended consequences for industry or could be more clear about the breadth of activity they were intended to encompass, it would have been an irresponsible government that was not prepared to introduce amending legislation. The minister was prepared to look at what was put to him, and this legislation is a consequence of those consultations. I think that it is always wise to take on board advice given to you, to digest it and to then decide whether the advice is appropriate or not. As a result of that process being followed, we are now debating the Copyright Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. Another point I would like to make is that this bill will not enable parties other than copyright owner or an exclusive licensee to force a service provider to take down allegedly infringing material. The safe harbour scheme is voluntary. A service provider is not forced to comply with the conditions in the safe harbour scheme, including items 11 and 13. A service provider can choose not to comply with the conditions in the safe harbour scheme, for example, by ignoring a notice that makes it apparent that material is likely to be infringing but, as a result, the service provider will not enjoy the limitations on remedies available under the scheme. A service provider that chooses to access the safe harbours is not obliged to take down material that is merely alleged by a party to infringe copyright. This bill provides that a service provider seeking to access the safe harbours need only act if it is apparent that the material is likely to be infringing. The bill recognises that constructive knowledge of infringements can arise through circumstances other than through notice from a copyright owner and that this is a clear Australia-US free trade agreement obligation. It is also consistent with US legislation that safe harbours be contingent on expeditious take-down once a service provider obtains constructive knowledge of infringement. I pointed out before that the government were of the view that Labor's amendments were unnecessary. That remains the government's view. We are not going to resile from that view, but we did not oppose the amendments in order that the bill could pass. The detriment to the Australian economy caused by Labor's recalcitrance would have been of such great moment that we believe that, on balance, it was better to allow the amendments to pass so that we could get the benefits of the historic Australia-US free trade agreement, which would not have occurred if the it had not been for the relationship between our government and the United States government. The exchange of letters between the Minister for Trade and the US Trade Representative covers a range of implementation issues. Mr Zoellick took the opportunity to restate the US's position on the Labor Party's amendments. The US continues to reserve its right to challenge their consistency with our international obligations at some stage. That is the US position. The government's position is as we have previously set out. It is good that there is a great deal of bipartisanship, shall we say, with regard to the substance of this bill. This bill tant element in the implementation of our free trade agreement obligations with the United States and, on that basis, I am particuwanted larly pleased to commend this legislation to the chamber.

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: I also rise to support the Copyright Legislation Amendment Bill 2004. I note and support the comments of my colleague the member for Hotham, our spokesperson on trade. He has covered very thoroughly Labor's position on the bill, the trade implications and our concerns in the copyright area. I intend to focus primarily on the copyright issues that will obviously have an impact in my portfolio area of Attorney-General. The government says that this bill makes various minor and clarifying amendments to the Copyright Act. Clearly, Labor does not view that as being the case. The amendments are not minor and are not clarifying. In fact, they are quite detailed and complex and in some areas remain of concern and confusion to the industry. They have important new implications, not so much for copyright owners themselves but for the disseminators of copyright material-in particular, Internet service providers. As you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, Labor did not negotiate the Australia-US free trade agreement but we did support it in parliament last August. We are now back again amending Australia's copyright laws because the government failed to get the detail right in the initial implementation bill. When Labor amended the bill that was put before the House to protect the PBS, the Prime Minister accused us of trying to knock over the deal. It is now clear that it was not Labor's amendments that were threatening the deal; rather, it was the government's failure to correctly legislate to give effect to what it alleges are Australia's obligations under the is a very imporfree trade agreement. With regard to copyright issues, it is apparent that the US knew very clearly what it when it entered into these negotiations and bargained hard for changes in the copyright areas-particularly the extension of Australia's copyright protection from 50 to 70 years from the death of the author. The government have admitted that this was their biggest concession to the US-a big concession with no apparent logic or analysis to support this change in Australia policy. Labor has expressed its view previously that it did not believe we should have extended copyright by a further 20 years. So in the light of this significant concession which was made as part of the package of the free trade agreement, it would have been reasonable to expect that Australia would have got something in return on copyright. Unfortunately, that was not the case and we see it even more clearly in this bill. The Copyright Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 amends the Copyright Act in response to concerns expressed by the US that the previous legislation had not met our free trade agreement obligations. The original free trade agreement implementation bill was enacted after the government accepted Labor's amendments, as I have noted before, to protect the integrity of the PBS and the Australian television local content rules. This bill has now been introduced by the government to correct what it and the US believe were the inadequacies in that original legislation. According to the government, this bill attempts to clarify the responsibilities, particularly of ISPs, in tion to infringing material posted on the Internet. Labor's second reading amendment goes to our concerns about the process followed to get the bill to this point and the uncertainty about the practical effect of the bill on significant players in the industry. I intend to structure the rest of my speech on this bill around the terms of Labor's second reading amendment, moved by the member for Hotham. Labor's amendment at part (a) notes with concern the failure of the government to previously correctly implement its obligations under the United States Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. We must say from the outset that it is disappointing that the issue was not effectively resolved in the first bill. These changes which the government now seeks to rush through in the final week of parliament for this year to meet the free trade agreement deadline of 1 January next year have caused considerable concern amongst some stakeholders in the Internet industry, after they had been led to believe that the original legislation in August covered their copyright obligations under the government's free trade agreement. Given that the government thought it was necessary to introduce the bill to clean up the perceived inadequacies, we believe there was an obligation on the government to thoroughly and effectively consult with the affected industry players who had had the original copyright regime pulled from underneath them. Unfortunately, we believe that this process has been botched. Strong concerns have been expressed by the Internet Industry Association, Internet service providers individually and the Australian Digital Alliance about both the consultation process and the effect of these proposed changes. These stakeholders believe that, while the government consulted with them on an earlier draft of the legislation, the bill now berelafore the House has added two significant changes: namely, items 11 and 13, which significantly expand the responsibilities of ISPs to monitor and take down material on their sites. In terms of the consultation process, major service providers believe the government should have been more transparent in its intentions and provided greater opportunity for feedback, particularly on these additional terms of the bill. The amendments are not, as I have noted before and as the government claims, minor and technical. In terms of the substance of the changes, ISPs, the Australian Digital Alliance and indeed the Labor Party are greatly concerned that these amendments will significantly expand the rights to demand the removal of material from the Internet beyond copyright holders and exclusive licensees to others. Part (b) of the second reading amendment which was moved by the member for Hotham deals in some more detail with these concerns in relation to take-down notices. We have concerns that the bill has the potential to enable persons other than copyright owners or exclusive licensees to force an Internet service provider to take down allegedly infringing copyright material from their system. This is no mild worry. The practice of computer-generated mass take-down notices being issued in the US, without any real person making an assessment of the material and potentially with no copyright interest involved, could, if the practice developed here with this new regime in place, put a heavy burden on our ISPs and therefore their customers, presumably through passing on any costs and perhaps with no resulting benefit to copyright owners. It is also the strong concern of some stakeholders that this bill goes beyond what is required by the free trade agreement in terms of copyright law and, in some people's view, beyond what is required by ISPs under the existing regime in the United States. I understand that the government disputes these claims. The expansion of the right to demand the taking down of infringing material going beyond copyright holders and exclusive licensees, or the potential for this expansion, has led to significant concerns amongst ISPs which include that access to safe harbour provisions will become unnecessarily onerous and that the process for complying with them is currently ill-defined and potentially unnecessarily difficult to comply with. Although the government says the use of these safe harbour provisions is optional, clearly ISPs want to be able to gain that protection if it is at all practicable. particular, the insertion of items 11 and 13 into the bill has placed an obligation on the ISPs-or carriage service providers, as they are termed in the bill-to expeditiously take down material if they are: ‘aware of facts or circumstances that make it apparent that the material is likely to be infringing'. ISPs and the Australian Digital Alliance have expressed grave concerns that this threshold test for the requisite knowledge is far too or at least not adequately defined by the act and would require them to take down a lot of material without much substance being required to the request that has been made. As already mentioned, it also does not require that a direction to take down material comes directly from the copyright owner or exclusive licensees. Labor is gravely concerned that this practically extends Australia's copyright laws so that someone other than the copyright owner or the exclusive licensee can require an ISP to take down allegedly infringing material and be forced into taking this action if they are to access the safe harbour provisions. The government has sought to assure the opposition that the relevant clause does not automatically require an ISP to take down material where there is merely an allegation of an infringement; the ISP need only act where there is a likelihood that the material is infringing. This, according to the government, is intended to ensure that the ISP can be held to have constructive knowledge of an infringement without the requirement that the copyright holder or exclusive licensee notify them. But we are also concerned that this could place a very heavy onus on the ISP to make an assessment of the validity of each and every claim that Internet material is infringing each and every time they receive some sort of notification that they are hosting infringing material. That is regardless of whether (a) the actual copyright owner or In exclusive licensee has requested the take down of the material or not; and (b) the notification on face value appears frivolous or is from some dubious source. They will still be worried that they need to take action to maintain their protection under the safe harbour provisions. As these terms are new to Australian copyright law, the ISPs are uncertain about the level of evidence that will meet the likelow lihood test. Understandably, they remain uncertain about what must be put before them to activate this test and therefore remain uncertain about how to gain protection against liability under the safe harbour provisions. The bill itself is silent on the rights and process for those who are accused of posting infringing material to contest a take-down notice. The government has informed us that these issues will be fleshed out in regulations. The member for Hotham has already expressed concerns that we must of course take this commitment on face value as the regulations in this regard have not been provided to us. Obviously, the government is on notice that we will pursue this commitment and examine closely the terms of the regulations when they are provided to us to ensure that these matters are adequately clarified. Part (1)(c) of the second reading amendment goes to the range of interests that need to be balanced between copyright owners, users and Internet service providers. As the terms of the amendment note, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee held a brief hearing on the effect of this bill on Monday night this week. At this hearing, several major stakeholders, including major ISPs, outlined their concernsmany of which I have already expressedthat the balance between the rights of copyright owners, users and the ISP has been disrupted. The reasons for their concerns have already been outlined. In contrast, the parliament should note that other stakeholders, like the Australian Record Industry Association and other copyright owners, are strongly supportive of the amendments in this bill. As also noted earlier, without the guidance of the regulations we feel it is difficult to true and accurate picture of how the copyright regime will operate after this bill comes into force and whether the balance is adequately maintained with the additional protections that will be forthcoming in the regulations. At the hearing of the committee on Monday, officers of the Attorney-General's Department could not be drawn on the content of the proposed regulations which will attempt to address this uncertainty and whether they will continue to consult with stakeholders. Once again, the House is being put in the position of assessing legislation of some significant impact without accompanying regulations that will affect the operation and impact of this legislation itself. Labor has no alternative but to accept the assurances received from the Minister for Trade and has no reason to doubt that they will not be kept. It is difficult for truly informed debate within this House to occur without all of the provisions being in front of us. Obviously, as the member for Hotham has also noted, we put strong emphasis on the assurances received from the trade minister that the concerns of ISPs in particular, as well as those of copyright users, will be resolved through the introduction of adequate regulations. The minister has made it quite clear in his correspondence that those regulations will flesh out the legislative safe harbour provisions and the rights and obligations of copyright owners, users and ISPs. Labor also draws some confidence from the minister's commitment that: ... the Government will keep implementation of the scheme under close review and, as necessary will consult with stakeholders on any issues that may arise, including appropriate responses. Labor will hold the government to its commitment to resolve the concerns of ISPs and copyright users in those accompanying regulations. ISPs and copyright users must monigain a tor the implementation of this scheme closely and promptly report any of their problems to the government as they arise. This is not an ideal outcome but-given the minimal time the parliament has to scrutinise these bills, and Australia's commitments under the FTA-it is the only way that we believe we can proceed at this point. In parts (1)(e) and (1)(f) of the second reading amendment, we raise issues of concern relating to the consultation process. We recognise that the government, as I have said, has committed to continuing to consult-or, I might say, ensuring that it does consult-widely with the industry to get its regulations right and ensure that those safe harbour provisions are workable for all in the industry. This will necessarily include a continuing review of the regulations to ensure that any inadequacies can be ironed out and that they can be made to operate fairly. We should put on record that the consultation process-particularly to date with stakeholders like the Internet Industry Association-has not been adequate in terms of the additional provisions that were added in this bill and in terms of providing a proper indication of the government's intention. It seems that this process has heightened rather than allayed people's concerns. Perhaps once the whole package is forthcoming those concerns will be shown to have been unnecessarily held. We certainly hope that this process in regard to the regulations will improve in the future, and our amendments make clear that we intend to hold the government to its commitment. Practical access to the safe harbour provisions is essential to ensure that there is a credible balance between effective action by ISPs to removing infringing material in the interest of copyright owners while at the same time providing fair protection against liability to both copyright owners and web site owners, who may be susceptible to having take-down notices issued against them. Again, adequate consultation with the industry is essential to ensure that these regulations are workable. Finally, I would like to cover the issue that has also been flagged in part (2) of our second reading amendment, in relation to pay TV piracy, because the bill does make further amendments to the copyright laws and makes clear that piracy of pay TV on a commercial scale is a criminal offence. But there are no sanctions in the bill on private piracy in the home. We do note with some apprehension that there is intended to be a review of Australia's laws in relation to the criminalisation of piracy of pay TV in the home and that Australia has committed to do that by 1 July next year. Again, we will be watching this process closely. As the member for Hotham also pointed out, Australian law has been based on the view that copyright breaches or piracy of pay TV that occurs in the home should be subject to civil and not criminal penalties. As the member for Hotham has indicated, we do not want to be in a position where teenagers can be subject to jail terms for this type of activity-such a penalty would be excessive. Clearly, this is not an unnecessary concern, given that action has been taken in some other countries against, for example, a 12-year-old-which I think is the latest example reported in the media-for this sort of activity. Part (2) of our second reading amendment calls on the government to again place on the record its difference of opinion with the US with regard to the criminalisation of pirated satellite signals in the home. It is imperative that the government gives this parliament an explanation of its commitment to the US to undertake this review of our domestic policy relating to the criminalisation of all forms of satellite signal piracy, including the unauthorised distribution or receipt of signals by commercial establishments and within the home. We would like the government to clearly put on record that it does not intend to change its long standing approach to dealing with these matters in the home in a civil rather than criminal manner. Obviously, we will be talking and working with the government as this review is undertaken and will make sure that our views are clearly known to the government as we have expressed them here today. In conclusion, it is clear that we are not in an ideal position while we are debating this bill today. It would not have been necessary to even be here and have this debate if the government had done its job properly to start with. There should have been a more comprehensive consultation process to iron out all the practical problems with the proposed changes, particularly for the ISP industry. Finally, the regulations should have been available to us and to stakeholders to assess in order for us to be able to debate the true impact of this bill. Nevertheless, we understand and accept the government's assurances and will keep an eager eye on future changes to ensure that these commitments are met. I commend the bill and the second reading amendment to the House.

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: The government, it seems, is not waiting until July next year to impose its arrogant disregard for process on this place. It seems that that is happening now, with the treatment of legislation in the past few days. I think that the Copyright Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 tops the list for contempt of proper process. I will just refer to a couple of comments that Senator Ridgeway made on this bill in the Senate-a speech, I must say, that was incorporated into Hansard because so little time was made available for proper debate. He said in part: The events of this week do not constitute the ate doing its job properly. I would add that they do not constitute this place doing its job either. He continued: The Government released the text of the Bill only days ago, after what seems like only the most cursory of consultations with Industry. The Minister describes the Bill as making ‘minor and technical' amendments, a claim that is patently falseaccording to Senator Ridgeway... Industry was consulted on a version of the that didn't even include the most controversial provisions. The Internet Industry Association, the Australian Digital Alliance and the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee have grave concerns about the content of the bill. Also, the Selection of Bills Committee in the Senate held an extraordinary meeting that had to report within 24 hours. That meeting lasted two hours. As I understand it, there was insufficient time for more than one substantial piece of evidence to be taken. All witnesses were asked to provide substantial amounts of further evidence on notice. Yet the bill has gone through the Senate and is back here for this second reading debate. The government, through its Minister for Trade, agreed in an exchange of letters with US trade representative Robert Zoellick to implement certain changes to the Copyright Act after the US determined that the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act 2004 did not fully implement certain provisions of the agreement. In no uncertain terms and with the clear threat by the US to take appropriate remedial action should Australia refuse to implement the changes demanded, this government has, true to form, rolled over and complied and so has removed any pretence that Australia had retained any flexibility in formulating its own exceptions to the stated rules. As noted in the Bills Digest, these letSen- ters agreeing to the changes and prescribing how obligations under the agreement will be implemented are now part of the legal interpretation of the agreement itself. Thus the FTA comes into force on 1 January whether this bill is passed or not. This has effectively obliged Australia to comply with new rules that have received no scrutiny or input from this parliament, and has in fact circumvented the parliament's ability to choose how best to apply the Bill agreement through law. There is no surprise here, given that the Australian parliament has had no opportunity to debate the terms of the free trade agreement itself but only the enabling legislation-and even then it was an empty debate that was allocated just 24 hours. So what are the changes to the agreement, achieved through the amendments to the Copyright Act under this current billchanges that the explanatory memorandum assures us are minor and technical? I want to point to three areas of concern. One area is temporary reproductions. In the current version of the agreement, temporary reproduction of a copyrighted item, such as the temporary copy stored in a DVD player's memory before transferring a picture to the screen, can be an infringement of copyright unless those copies fall under an exception. One of the listed exceptions prevents the normal playing of digital media, as described above, from being an infringement as long as the reproduction is temporary and a necessary part of a technical process of use, as described above. Thus if the copy of the movie lodges itself somewhere in the dark recesses of memory in your DVD or computer for the longer term, it is an infringement of copyright. An exception to this exception is if the original media is itself an infringing copy. The bill deals with another exception to the exception. This is where the exception does not apply, where the original copy is from another country and would be an infringing copy if it had been made in Australia. Note that in this case the infringing could be a legitimately licensed copy in the country from which it is bought, legitimately bought in that country and then brought to Australia by your unsuspecting consumer. Thus we now have a situation where not only the actual copying and selling of an infringing item is illegal but where simply watching or listening to a DVD that an Australian has legitimately bought in, say, the US, will, as understand it, be an infringing act. Under the existing act, such a person fered protection from criminal prosecution in that ‘profit' is defined to exclude private or domestic use. An infringement does, however, open up the possibility of civil action. Any protection in the existing Copyright Act is rendered somewhat ambiguous with the new exception to the exception. Thus we now have a situation in which the government is agreeing to severely limit the right of a consumer to do what they want with property they have legally purchased. Here we have Australia agreeing to police, on behalf of the copyright owners, the exclusive right of the copyright owners to determine an Australian individual's personal use of legitimately purchased works. There are yet more effects flowing from this seemingly minor amendment-this exception to the exception-that are incredibly counterintuitive to the idea of free trade of a free market. Intuitively it is understood that a healthy market economy depends on different companies being allowed to compete with each other and so driving the market to efficiency. That is a basic law of the market; this is free trade. However, there is a real possibility this bill may constitute an effective ban on parallel importing. Parallel importing is when a copyrighted product is legitimately purchased in one country, where it was legally manufactured under licence from the IP holder, and imported to compete on the Australian market as a generally cheaper copy product. A clear example was raised by Weiss et al about the Australia-US free trade agreement in their book How to Kill a Country. I refer people to the book for their Christmas stockings. It is the importing into Australia of a drug that is produced cheaply under licence in India, rather than from the actual patent owner, who is invariably producing the same drug at triple the cost in the I US. Here is where parallel importing, so vital to a healthy market economy, could be renis ofdered a criminal offence according to my reading. The second point is criminal provisions. Section 10 of the existing copyright legislation states that a non-infringing copy is: ... a non-infringing [article] whose importation does not infringe that copyright. So far so good. A non-infringing article is a non-infringing article. Theoretically this allows parallel importation. However, the discussed exception to the exception-as the exception does not apply where the original copy is from another country and would be an infringing copy if it had been made in Australia-begs clarification as to whether this also applies to legally imported goods that are legally manufactured under licence in another country. This is an incredibly important point because if such imports could be considered infringing copies then their importation would also be considered a criminal act due to the ‘by way of trade' and ‘obtaining commercial advantage or profit' provisions of the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Bill 2004. That said, the Copyright Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 goes another step towards easing the requirement of prosecutors to demonstrate that infringements were performed by way of trade and with the intention of obtaining a commercial advantage or profit, to having to demonstrate only one of these items by way of trade or with the intention of obtaining a commercial advantage or profit. This brings me back to the temporary copy amendments represented by the bill, copies which theoretically have little or no economic significance to most copyright holders-or do they? Kim Weatherall, Associate Director of the Intellectual Property Research Institute of Australia and Lecturer in Law at Melbourne University, makes it clear that it is about market monopoly and raising barriers to competitors in the marketplace. Consider these points Ms Weatherall raises on her Internet page-points that are recognised internationally as matters of concern. The inclusion of temporary copies into copyright protection laws has enabled copyright owners to try to force video stores to buy more expensive ‘rental' versions of films despite the absence of an exclusive rental right. This inclusion has been used in litigation by Sony to argue for the current incredibly anticompetitive practice of embedding regional playing codes into DVDs and DVD players to allow them to work only when the same are bundled with the same. My recollection is that this practice got Microsoft in some trouble. In the US, copyright for temporary copies has been used to corner the market for software troubleshooting services. I question whether the same sort of services provided by the plethora of Australian computer businesses would fall under the commercial advantage provisions that incur criminal penalties under Australian law. In Canada, Ms Weatherall suggests, it has been used as an argument to make ISPs liable for activities of their users. My third point is on probably the most publicly contentious part of the bill, under which carriage service providersbusinesses that supply Internet or telecommunications-may be liable for their customers' breaches of these copyright laws. When a person uses an internet service provider to transmit or store infringing information, even storing it on the user's own systems, uses it to host a website or uses the provider's search engine to visit an online location that breaches copyright, that provider is now liable. In the original bill the service provider was liable for criminal prosecution if the provider received financial benefit and if they were aware of the practice and did not act to stop it. ‘Financial benefit' did not include usage fees from the offending user, nor did it include increased income from a higher level of use due to lower charges. This bill replaces actual knowledge of the infringement with having received notification only, which may be spurious, and determines that financial benefit could be something as innocuous as the difference between ‘industry practice in relation to charging for services' and what the CSP charges. Whose industry, whose practicewhat exactly does that particular phrasing mean? It is clear that any service provider who is providing and benefiting from keen competition by offering lower user fees is immediately open to suffering abuse under these provisions. It may be that this government could be complicit in stifling innovation and competitive pricing in an industry that is known for exactly those qualities. Now CSPs can be liable even if they are not aware or could not reasonably have been aware that infringement is occurring on their network. This is a requirement of the FTA. Australian CSPs, in order to avoid criminal prosecution, must expend their time and energy policing other people's copyrights. This promises to be a considerable use of resources that has the potential to severely pact on a service provider's operations and, indeed, viability. In the US, copyright owners and ‘hired guns' use computers to trawl the internet, automatically issuing ‘take down' notices to CSPs and threatening legal action. These infringements need not be valid, but they are enough to censor material or seriously disrupt a competitor's business, with hundreds of thousands of such notices being issued in the US already. There exists in our legislation no procedural fairness to protect service providers targeted. The minister may say that it is all going to be covered under regulations, so I will be interested to see what they are and why indeed they have not been available. There is no process required to determine whether there is in fact a copyright ment before the material must be removed, and there is no protection for CSPs, who are between the devil and the deep blue sea. They face potential liability as regards their customers if they remove material that is not infringing copyright, or they face liability as regards the copyright owners if the material does infringe copyright, which itself is a far wider net than ever before. I have said before that the Australia-US free trade agreement is antithetic to free trade and market competition. It subjugates Australia's sovereignty in favour of protecting aggressive and monopolistic markets and, in this case, potentially diminishes competition in the huge global IT market and the rights of Australian consumers to choose. None of these issues have been on the public agenda enough. I have just got my head around the consequences. They need much further debate and exposure, as indeed does the US FTA, but there is no time for that. Under the current circumstances I certainly cannot support this bill, and I invite the minister to respond to my concerns.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: COPYRIGHT LEGISLATION
text: I thank the members for Hotham, Fisher, Gellibrand and Calare for their contribution in this debate. The Copyright Legislation Amendment Bill 2004 is an important step in the process that will lead to the commencement of the AustraliaUnited States free trade agreement on 1 January next year. I would like to remind the House about the signing of the agreement that has been struck with the largest and most dynamic economy in the world. It is a historic achievement that this government is so proud of, as should be the whole Australian community, for the overall benefits it will bring to the country. This debate is about a specific section of the agreement: matters relating to copyright. I note that the member for Calare is inviting a wider debate, but I do infringenot intend to take that up. The copyright provisions in the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act 2004 passed by the parliament in August were fully consistent with our obligations. I also remind the House that those copyright provisions were extensive and covered a number of important areas of reform. It is not surprisduct ing that some finetuning and clarification has been required in some areas in the bill that is before us today. I repeat that the amendments are mostly minor and technical in nature and involve no changes to the agreement or major policy changes to the Copyright Act. It would have been irresponsible for the government not to clarify the practical operation of certain provisions once industry concerns were raised. The member for Hotham has today raised some matters arising from the Minister for Trade's letter to him addressing concerns in relation to Internet service providers. I do propose to address these issues in detail, but I should make a couple of observations. First, the concerns that the ISPs have about the conditions in items 11 and 13 of the bill, in relation to automatic bot notices, need to be put in context. The safe harbour scheme is not compulsory. The ISPs can choose to not comply with the conditions in items 11 and 13 of the bill and to not respond to takedown notices. This means that carrier service providers do not take advantage of safe harbour provisions, which reduces the remedies available to them, and their liability is determined under existing law. Second, many of the ISP concerns relate to matters that are probably being dealt with in the regulations which are currently being prepared. I met with representatives of the ISPs and gave them my assurance that we would consult with them on the regulations. I want to emphasise the Minister for Trade's commitment that the government will keep implementation of the scheme under close review and, as necessary, consult with stakeholders should any matters arise. One final matter raised by the member for Hotham concerned the pay-TV piracy review. Australia does have a different approach to issues of criminalisation of conin the home in relation to unauthorised satellite signals. It is our view that the trade agreement did not require criminalisation of activity of this type. However, domestic stakeholders have raised the issue with the government. For this reason, the government have undertaken to conduct a comprehensive review of the law. The review is appropriate-no decision has been made on this issue-and it will commence in early 2005 and hopefully be completed by July. The opposition has proposed an amendment. The amendment will not be supported by the government. Some aspects of it are not unexceptional, but there are other comments in it that we find unacceptable and for that reason we oppose it in totality. The government believes that the amendments in this bill will continue the ongoing improvement of Australia's copyright laws. The amendments will ensure that Australia's reputation for having legislation providing for strong copyright protection is maintained. It will ensure our legislation remains comparable to the standards of our major trading partners. Both copyright owners and users will benefit from the changes that clarify the practical effect of the amendments made to the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act 2004. The government will always aim to achieve copyright legislation that strikes an appropriate balance between the rights of owners and the rights of users. I remind those who continue to harbour doubts about the provisions of the bill or who believe that copyright law reform will cease that further reviews of copyright legislation in a number of important areas are planned in the near future. I again thank all those members who have contributed to the debate and thank the House for its support for the bill. Hopefully we can wind it up quickly.

Speaker: Mr RUDDOCK
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That this bill be now read a second time. The fight against the illicit drug trade in Australia and internationally remains a high priority for the Australian government, consistent with the government's Tough on Drugs strategy. The offences of importing and exporting illicit drugs across Australia's national border are some of the most serious federal offences. In relation to drugs such as heroin, judges have the capacity to impose sentences of up to 25 years imprisonment where the offence involves a trafficable quantity of the drug and up to life imprisonment where the offence involves a commercial quantity. Consequently, sentences of life imprisonment have been handed down. To date, the option of life imprisonment has not been available in relation to certain other illicit drugs, such as amphetamines, because the Customs Act has not prescribed ‘commercial quantities' for those drugs. I understand in a recent case involving the importation of 200 kilograms of methylamphetamine, known as ‘ice', the judge suggested that, if there was a commercial quantity listed, he would have been able to consider imposing a life imprisonment penalty. In that case, the maximum penalty that could be imposed was the penalty for the lower threshold ‘trafficable quantity', being 25 years imprisonment. Prior to the judge's comments, the Attorney-General's Department sought to address this issue by preparing regulations but have concluded that this could not be done because the drugs in question are already listed in the act. This bill will prescribe commercial quantities for all illicit drugs currently covered the drug importation offences in the Customs Act and therefore ensure that judges have the full spectrum of penalties available to them when sentencing those found guilty of importing large quantities of any illicit drug, including new and emerging drugs. The Australian government is committed to a proactive approach to ensure that judges will always have the capacity to make the penalty for drug offences reflect the seriousness of the crime. Next year the government will be bringing forward further improvements, including new serious drug offences for inclusion in the Criminal Code. In the meantime, it is essential that this anomaly in relation to sentences be addressed. I therefore commend the bill for speedy passage, and present the explanatory memorandum. Leave granted for second reading debate to continue immediately.

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I rise to speak on and support the Customs Amendment Bill 2004 and the message from the Senate. This is an important piece of legislation that seeks to enhance sentencing options available to judges in cases where individuals are caught smuggling commercial quantities of dangerous drugs as defined under schedule VI of the Customs Act 1901. For the benefit of members, schedule VI of the act proscribes a list of 130 narcotic substances, each with a specified amount known as a trafficable quantity-that is, a quantity associated with low-level drug dealing. This means that anyone in possession of a trafficable quantity can be charged under provisions that prevent that level of drug dealing. However, as the schedule currently stands, only 21 of these substances specify an amount known as a commercial quantitythat is, a quantity associated with high-level drug dealing. The reason why the other 109 by substances did not have commercial quantities specified at the time is simply that, to the best of everyone's knowledge, they were not being imported in commercial quantities, nor was this foreseen by legislators in introducing the original act. The intention of differentiating between trafficable and commercial quantities is a good idea, and I am certainly pleased that Labor can contribute to tightening up the provisions regarding the other 109 substances listed in schedule VI. By defining a commercial quantity for these substances, this bill adds a sentencing option for judges that includes life imprisonment. The maximum current penalty available for illegal importation of these substances is 25 years, because that is the maximum penalty for importation of trafficable quantities. By spelling out the commercial quantities as we do in this bill, we allow for judges to impose a more severe sentence for people who seek to import dangerous substances into our country. Labor are concerned about the importation of illegal drugs into this country and we fully support the excellent work of the Australian Customs Service and the Australian Federal Police in their recent successes against drug importers. The amount of MDMA, also known as ecstasy, that has been detected by Customs has almost doubled over the last two years. That is excellent work, but by no means has this put a stop to the availability of this drug in the community, as recent reports in the media show. From figures from the Parliamentary Library and the Customs Service it is clear that more ecstasy is being imported into Australia. As recently as 1993 there were few seizures of ecstasy at the customs barrier. In 1994, 2.9 kilograms were seized. However, just in the period from January to August 1996, 29.9 kilograms were seized. Astoundingly, in 2003-04 that figure was 873 kilograms, so there has been a frightening increase. There is also evidence to suggest that Australia could again be the target of drug lords who wish to import heroin. Members may be interested to know that, since the removal of the Taliban in Afghanistan, opium poppies have returned to the fields as an acceptable cash crop for farmers. The effect of more heroin coming onto the market may well make Australia an increased target for heroin imports over the coming few years. Labor will be monitoring this situation closely and will be holding the government to account for any increased availability of this most insidious drug. Members, there are a number of steps that Labor has taken to satisfy itself that this bill will not have an unjust effect. Firstly, this bill will not be retrospective. Secondly, I have checked the bill and it does not make any attempt to modify or vary the existing commercial quantities specified for 21 schedule VI drugs. Further, and finally, Labor has successfully amended the bill in the Senate to include a 12-month sunset clause that will enable all members and senators to review and scrutinise the effectiveness of these measures before more substantial changes are made. I remind members of the House that the bill is providing an additional option to judges but is not inserting any mandatory provisions. To that extent, the bill is a stopgap measure, but it is a measure Labor have considered carefully and amended to ensure the safeguard of a sunset clause. We recognise, in light of recent court decisions referred to by the Attorney in his second reading speech, that there is a valid reason for this measure. In short, this bill will have the effect of making additional penalties available to the courts in the very serious area of illicit drug importation in commercial quantities. That is a worthy goal. Labor are happy to support that goal and therefore commend the bill to the House.
