Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: VALEDICTORY
text: As the House comes to an end for this year, in the tradition, I would like to extend first to you, Mr Speaker, brief though your occupancy in the chair has been, the very best of good wishes for Christmas and the New Year, to thank you for your many courtesies already to me and the House and to wish you and your family every happiness over the Christmas break. To the clerks-to Ian Harris and to Bernard Wright in particular, both of whom exemplify the very best traditions of independence and integrity in the discharge of their duties-we owe a very special thanks. In the 30 or more years I have been in parliament, I have marvelled at the capacity of Hansard to make good sense of what many of us say. Unlike a lot of other members, I have never really bothered to correct my greens. I always thought it was a slightly impertinent thing to do. Can I say that, after 30 years, Hansard has never got me into trouble. So if I have got into any trouble, it has been all of my own making. But I do want to thank Hansard very warmly, along with the very wonderfully polite and friendly attendants who make our life as we sit here a lot more enjoyable. I do particularly wish them well. They are a very polite, friendly people. They dart around helping us, and I do want to especially wish them a very merry Christmas. To all the other parliamentary staff, the Commonwealth car pool and those who arrange the bookings-I was a little more familiar with the arrangements of travel bookings a few years ago than perhaps I am now, but I have not forgotten the enormous courtesy of all of those who do that I do want to express my great gratitude to them. This has been of course a remarkably active year. It has had the added spice of an election on 9 October, which was very pleasing for the coalition. We have had the opportunity of coming back for three weeks and that has been particularly important for the new members. There have been new members on both sides of the House and many of them are sitting in on this debate. I want to particularly welcome them again to the great institution of the national parliament of Australia. I hope all of them have a long stay. I say that very genuinely. We would be very happy if the numbers remained exactly as they are. I wish no ill will at all to new members on the other side of the House. We can live without winning seats like Prospect, Kingsford Smith and Watson, to name but three. Mr Murphy-And Lowe.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: VALEDICTORY
text: Yes. To my good friend the member for Lowe, it was a bit negligent of us that he got there, but then he works it hard, and I understand that. We can live with that, with the status quo. I can genuinely say that I wish all of those members a long parliamentary life. If everybody stayed exactly where they were for a few years, it would be terrific. That applies to a large number of people. I especially say to the new members: ‘Welcome. I hope you have been made welcome.' Speaking for myself on behalf of the coalition, I express my pride in the quality of the new members that have come into the government ranks. They come from very diverse backgrounds. They bring different talents and different skills and their own different personalities. Some of them came easily, and some of them had two fights-I can think of one who did: he had a preselection fight and then he had an election fight. For others, it all suddenly happened in a rush-I can think of somebody who falls into that category. I can think of other members who had to work very, very hard for eight, nine or 12 months to win seats from the other side of politics-one succeeded a very distinguished member of this House who had been a wonderful colleague for a number of years. They have all brought something new and something different. That is what this parliament must do: it must reflect the breadth of the Australian community. Both political parties have a challenge. It is a challenge for the Labor Party and it is a challenge for our party as well. We live in a time of declining political party memberships. When political party memberships decline, the decision making processes of political parties fall into the hands of fewer and fewer people and the tendency to reward mediocrity, to try and hold out the outsiders and to think that you preselect people on the basis of it being his or her turn next will in time produce a lower quality of members of parliament. That does not apply to anybody who is here now, but let me say that it is a warning for the future and I am very serious about it. If we end up with a parliament full of people whose only life experience has been politics and nothing else then we will have a very narrowly based parliament. That is very important. There is nothing like having a parliament that is made up of all of the Australian people. It applies to both sides of politics, let me say-it is a challenge that we all face. I will give a couple of personal thanks. I want to thank John Anderson, the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party, for the wonderful support that he has given me through the year. I have spoken of this before, but I will speak of it is no more inherently decent human being in public life than the Deputy Prime Minister. I thank him very much for the support and friendship of these past years. To the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the person who I think is the finest Treasurer this country has had, I express my very special thanks for his stewardship of the economy, his loyalty and support to me and the way in which he prosecuted the government side of the economic case in the election campaign. I express to him, his wife, Tanya, and their family my great thanks. I also give my thanks to Senator Robert Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and Senator Nick Minchin, the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Senate, of course, has not been an easy chamber for us; it will continue to be a more difficult chamber for us for some months yet. They do a great job and I thank them very warmly for that. To all of my ministerial colleagues I owe a special debt of gratitude. One of the strengths of the government has been its unity and its sense of common direction and only common purpose. That has been a great deal behind the government's success in recent times. To my personal staff I owe a special debt of gratitude. Arthur Sinodinos, my chief of staff, has now been with me in that position since the end of 1997. He is a person who had a very good background in the Public Service but adapted to the political environment whilst preserving the respect and cooperation of the Public Service. He has done it very effectively. To Tony Nutt, who I often say knows where more Liberal Party bodies are buried-particularly in Western Australia-than anybody in my party, I express a special debt of gratitude. To Tony O'Leary, who has to deal with the ladies and gentlemen of the media, if I can put it that way, and does it very well, and to David Luff and all the other members of my staff I exagain: there press very special thanks. Particularly, this year, I want to put on record my gratitude to Brian Loughnane, the federal director of the Liberal Party, who was the organisational chieftain of our magnificent election campaign, and to the federal president, Shane Stone. I will have the opportunity, with my other leadership colleagues, of meeting the federal executive of the Liberal Party in Canberra tomorrow. It is an opportunity to convey both tomorrow and tonight my great gratitude to the party organisation. I am very happy to say that everything I have achieved in politics I owe to the Liberal Party. I will never forget what Liberal Party has meant to me; I will never forget what the Liberal Party has done for me. I would never have been a member of parliament without the Liberal Party; I certainly would never have been Prime Minister without the support of my Liberal Party colleagues. Sometimes all of us can get a little carried away with just how large our personal votes might be in our electorate. Sometimes, when you do the analysis of these things, it is very sobering indeed to realise that. What I find very sobering sometimes is that you can have a long-serving memberthis applies on both sides-who retires and is replaced by a completely unknown person and, because of the change in the broad political climate, the completely unknown person does infinitely better than the longserving member that he or she replaced. Therefore, I express my particular thanks to Brian and Shane and all their organisational colleagues for what they have done for us. I also extend my very best wishes to the Leader of the Opposition and his wife, Janine, and to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and all the other members of the Australian Labor Party. I particularly welcome the new members who have joined us. They represent a different perspective but, nonetheless, I know they come here determined to make an impact and determined to change things for the better. All people, with a few exceptions, come into this place determined to try and improve life for their fellow citizens. I do not think we do each other any good by suggesting that there is total malice residing in the breasts of our opponents and total merit residing on our side of politics. People are really motivated to go into public life for the very best of reasons, and most people I have met in this place have got that motivation. This is, of course, an occasion of the year that celebrates the birth of the most signifithe cant figure in human history, Jesus of Nazareth. It is an occasion to acknowledge the spiritual component of our lives. That is not compulsory. We live in a society where faith is matter of personal choice, and millions of Australians lead their lives according to the Christian religion. A smaller, but nonetheless totally respected, number lead their lives according to other faiths. Many choose not to lead their lives according to any faith at all. That is entirely a matter of personal choice. One of the driving philosophical forces of Christianity is individual choice and free will, and faith in the Christian sense is based very much on an individual choice and an individual embrace of a set of spiritual values. For my part I have endeavoured, completely inadequately, to live as best I can according to the basic tenets of the Christian religion. It is not something that most Australians choose to wear on their sleeve quite as much as some from other countries do. It does not alter the fact that there is a deep deposit of spirituality in this country which is a very, very strong force for good. For all the brickbats that have been hurled at the Christian churches and for all their failings and for all the failings, personal sins and indiscretions of some of their members, it remains the fact that the Christian religion is the greatest force for good, progress and dignity of the individual in this nation. There is no force which is greater for the enhancement of individuals and the liberation of the human spirit. I think it is important at a time like this for those who attest to that view to express it, as I do, but I do that in no sense of stricture against those who hold a different point of view. I respect very strongly the secular traditions of this country. I will never be one that will seek to define the worth of somebody's contribution to public life according to whether or not they hold a particular religious point of view. We are a society that respects all religions, but we should respect our own history and our own traditions. We should not run away from the influence of Judaeo-Christianity on this country. It has been an enormous force for good and it has shaped not only the individual lives of people but also the character of our nation. We will be a poorer nation if we shrink from an understanding of that influence and from the impact that it has had. In that spirit, can I wish all members of the parliament the very best for Christmas. Have a good time with your families. I intend to. I intend to have a holiday, and I hope the Leader of the Opposition does. I mean that sincerely; I do not mean that in any facetious sense. He has a young family. I remember what it was like when my children were that age. It is important that we do spend a lot of time with our children, particularly at that age. As they get older they spend a little less time with you, I can report, but nonetheless quite a bit, and the bonds that develop with your children at the age that the Leader of the Opposition's are at are the bonds that make it the case that when they have grown up to adulthood they still want you around-selectively and occasionally, as we all understand. To have a good relationship with your adult children is the most satisfying thing that you can have in life because it is a completely consensual, voluntary thing and it is based upon mutual respect and the compatibility of personalities. I wish the Leader of the Opposition well. I wish all of my parliamentary colleagues well and, as was a tradition that I developed with one of his predecessors, I extend a handshake to the Leader of the Opposition, wish him well for the Christmas period and look forward to seeing him back in the New Year. Honourable members-Hear, hear!

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: VALEDICTORY
text: I join with the Prime Minister in extending good wishes to the members of the parliament, to the staff of the parliament-who deserve to be recognised on this important occasion-and, of course, to the people of the country at such a special part of the year. Politics is a great vocation. It is a chance to serve the people in public office. It is much more than a contest, it is a great distinction, and I am sure in an election year the members who have contested their seats successfully understand the nature of the distinction. Sometimes in the heat of the battle we forget about the importance of democracy itself-that each of us come with a heavy responsibility to try and build public trust and confidence in the institution itself. I always try and make the point, in attempting to get young people more interested in politics, that when they look at the TV news at night they can see many unhappy examples of how countries are not being run harmoniously and successfully-nations that do not have democratic freedoms and democratic rights. Hopefully around the country Australians are thankful that in an election year, notwithstanding the disappointment we had in the result, the elections were free and fair. That is something to celebrate and something we should always be mindful of in this democratic chamber, particularly as we try and encourage young people to value the importance of our democracy and add to it in future years. We do need to encourage all Australians to have a higher opinion of our democracy. In the Labor Party we fancy ourselves as the party of change and often feel that our burden is doubly difficult in that we have to encourage people to be interested not only in politics but also in the prospects of progressive change in our society. That for us is one of the foundations of our beliefs, and I am sure all members going into the Christmas period after the white heat battle of an election campaign know the importance of having democratic trust and the confidence of the Australian people. Like the Prime Minster, I wish all the members of the parliament, their partners and their families the best over the Christmas period. It is a special time of the year. I have always regarded it as the best time of the year, because no matter what you have been doing-your vocation, your calling, your interest, your job-you come together with the joy of giving, the joy of family and the joy of giving love to those that you are close to. I wish the Prime Minister and his family all the very best through the festive season, and also the party leaders and their families: the Nationals, the Independents, the Democrats, the Greens, other party interests around the parliament and all members in this place. All senators work hard, but I rather fancy that party leaders have extra burdens to bear and perhaps look forward to the holiday period and the love of our families with particular relish. All the members do work hard, but on this side of the House I want to particularly acknowledge the range of people who have contributed to the management of opposition business. I wish them and their families all the best-in particular the member for Lalor, the member for Grayndler and the member for Hotham. In particular I want to thank one of the advisors to the member for Lalor. We all know she is a brilliant tactician and strategist and we always value her contributions in the House, but behind every great female tactical genius is a good man-that man has been Jamie Snashall-‘Sasha' to his mates-and we thank him for his service over the past 12 months in helping to pull together the question time tactics and information each sitting day. That is not the easiest task in the parliament, but he has done it well, contributing to the opposition. Together with Phillippe Allen and now Jack Lake in my office, all the members of the opposition pay tribute to Jamie's service and we hope that our party, tonight in humour, is going to lift its standard compared to past efforts. In terms of his real vocation, politics and public service, we wish him well in the future. Mr Speaker, I extend to you, your wife, Penny, and your family all the best for the Christmas period. We know we have given you something of a baptism of fire in the last couple of weeks, but let me assure you that it is good for you. It is character building. The Prime Minister, a man of endurance in public life, knows that sometimes you have to do it tough to reap the rewards later on. I am sure that you understand the goodwill and good wishes that the opposition extends to you for the Christmas period and the term of parliament ahead. I also wish to convey my best wishes to your predecessor, Neil Andrew, who is fondly regarded on all sides of the parliament and who served this chamber with such distinction. We wish him and his family all the best over the Christmas period and the years ahead. On the Labor side I thank my deputy, Jenny Macklin, for her hard work. I am sure she is looking forward to the Christmas period with her family and her loved ones. I thank all the shadow ministers past and present we have had on the Labor side for their special contribution-the Labor MPs and the Senate team so well led over the years by John Faulkner and now Chris Evans. I pay particular credit and tribute to John Faulkner who, to me, epitomises the best of Labor culture-a man of true solidarity and principle. He is a true believer in the best sense left of centre politics. His contribution has been particularly important to us and I know that he deserves the break with his family and loved ones in the weeks ahead. I also want to say a special thankyou to the Labor Party supporters who worked for our cause and our campaign in the recent election-the true believers who put in, notwithstanding the disappointment of the result. When you struggle for a better society the cause always matters and the effort always matters-and, from Tim Gartrell down, I thank every single Labor partisan who worked so hard throughout 2004. I also want to thank the staff of the par- services. liament who make this place function so well. At one level we have the easy part of it-we turn up in a highly functional and efficient building to serve the people of Australia but we should always be very thankful for those who serve us in this large building. It is not an easy task. The people who work here are great servants of our democratic system. So I thank the attendants, the clerks, their staff, the table office and all of those who add to the smooth functioning of the democratic chamber and the parliament. Along with the Prime Minister I thank Hansard-you get into these jobs and you do not get to correct the greens as much as you might have as a backbencher-they make sense of our words and do a tremendous job. They keep us safe and sound in the way we communicate to the Australian people and the historians who will look at all these illustrious debates in years ahead and try to make some sense of them. I thank the staff of the Parliamentary Library. I do not see them as much as I used to. Not only has it come about that I am not writing books these days but I am not reading as many as I used to. So I do not see them but I know that they are providing an of exceptionally professional and comprehensive service to all the members and senators. Along with the Prime Minister I urge the new members in this place to not only put in, be enthusiastic and do their work hard and well, but also make good use of the library. We are well served here. We have one of the best parliamentary libraries in the Western world. We should thank the information staff and the research staff-and the new members here would do themselves a good service to use that library as effectively as possible. Labor members, of course, will use it well. Government members can also make good use of the library and be thankful for its I thank the Serjeant-at-Arms and the office that make all things work so well. I thank the Joint House staff, who keep this fine building in great nick and cater to our needs. I thank the cleaners and those who maintain the grounds and the rooms of the parliament-the cleaners in particular. If you ever get in here very early in the morning or tend to leave late at night you will see the cleaners moving in and around the building. I have a soft spot for the cleaners-my mum was one. So to the cleaners who look after us and clean up after us: we really do thank you for that effort in the dark of night, in tough working conditions. To keep our rooms and the space of the parliament so clean and neat is a great tribute to you. They are, in many respects, the silent heroes of the building as they move around. I want to wish them a particularly happy Christmas and I look forward to seeing them in 2005. I thank the marketing and visiting staff, who do such a great job in bringing thousands of schoolchildren and visitors through the parliament. Visitors see the good and the bad of our work and they get a first-hand view of the place. I think that practical experience counts for a lot more than just viewing the parliament through television. I thank the switchboard staff. They always work hard, particularly in an election year. They do a great job, and we thank them for their courtesy and their pleasant way of handling our calls and needs through the switchboard. I thank the caterers, who help us to put the weight on; I thank the health and recreation staff, who help us to take a small portion of it off-never enough, of course, but they do a great service to the parliament and its members. I want to thank the staff of the opposition-the people who work hard for us in a very practical way-and in particular my personal staff. People do these jobs for the right reason and the right purpose. It is not for the public profile or the personal glorification that might come in a successful public life. The staff behind the scenes are doing things on the basis of belief and conviction. From George Thompson down, in my office and right through the opposition offices, I thank them for their hard work in opposition, which can be frustrating and exacting, but they really and truly put in for the cause of Labor in 2004. In my electorate of Werriwa, where it is always a great distinction and honour to serve such a wonderful Labor constituencyI have not been there as much in 2004 because of my party leadership responsibilities-I want to thank in a special way my electorate office staff, headed by Lyn Watson but also including Vicki Meadows, Michelle Halloran and Louise Makings for their work in looking after the people of Werriwa. I want to thank my campaign staff and the electors of the seat, who continue to give me the great distinction of serving in this place on their behalf. As we head into the holiday period, I want to pay particular tribute to the volunteers of our nation, the quiet heroes who selflessly put themselves in harm's way to protect life and property-people like our volunteer firefighters and lifeguards. While we look forward to Christmas and we know it is a great country in which to spend December and January, we also know it can be a harsh and punishing nation. Unfortunately there will inevitably be difficulties through the Christmas period, and we should always be grateful for the work of the volunteers and professional people who deal with those problems and issues. Also, I want to pay tribute to the volunteers who serve in silence but with no less distinction: our carers and community service workers. I also thank the young men and women of our armed forces, where Australia has always been so well served. Regardless of our views on the issues of international policy, we always unite as a parliament and we always support our Australians overseas. We thank them for their contribution and their dedication to our great nation. I also extend best wishes to the members of our diplomatic corps and our foreign aid workers. As the bombing in Jakarta so terribly demonstrated, these days they are very much in the frontline in the war against terror. They defend our national interests and serve the country so well. We should wish them a very good Christmas and thank them for their service to the nation, in particular those Australian aid workers overseas. I always believe that as a parliament we need to do more, as we visit overseas locations, to come back with stories of the productive work of the Australian aid budget. In recent years, I have been to ghettos in Delhi and Jakarta where you can see how the Australian aid contribution helps to feed people. It helps to keep them alive. It is a wonderful service to humanity. At a time when people do wonder about the allocation of scarce government resources, we should always promote the value of the Australian foreign aid budget and the wonderful service it provides to Third World nations and people in absolutely desperate need. So I thank them for their work. They will have a challenging Christmas, as they always do in locations like that, just to keep people going and give them the dignity of a decent human life. I wish the Australian people a very happy Christmas and a safe and rewarding new year. We are a prosperous nation. It is always said that we are a lucky country, but we cannot take the luck for granted. As we reflect on our joyous Christmas and the love, sharing and giving of family, we should also spare a thought for those Australians who do it tough right throughout the yearAustralians who live in poverty. At this time of the year I urge all Australians to give erously of their time and resources to the great charities that look after the poor, the disadvantaged and the disabled. They work right around the year, but that work counts so much more at Christmas time, when we need to share the love and emotion and the caring nature of our country. I wish all Australians safe and happy Christmas. Finally, in a very special way, I want to thank my family for their love and encouragement through the course of this year-my wife, Janine; our two wonderful little boys, Oliver and Isaac; my mother; my sisters; and my family. Like other members of the parliament, I desperately long to spend extended time with them in the weeks and months ahead. I look forward to that very much. When we reflect on the love of family, that truly is the spirit of Christmas. I wish all Australians to share in it and all members of this parliament to feel the love and care of this special part of the year.

Speaker: Mr ANDERSON
Title: VALEDICTORY
text: I would like to begin by briefly saying that I think it is appropriate for us to lift our minds from the day-today political debate and the headlines to recognise the great achievement that makes these valedictories possible. Once again, the Australian people have chosen their government peacefully, through a wellordered election, not through civil strife or a palace coup. What a blessing that is. The Leader of the Opposition has just acknowledged that the opposition lost, fairly; they still have a very important constitutional role in this chamber. We as a government recognise of course that our stewardship of the country will again be judged by the Australian people in 2007. Peaceful elections are of course a tremendous historic achievement, one that men and women in their millions down through the ages have died for. Today, in many countries less fortunate than ours, genmen and women across the world still long for, fight for and risk everything for this achievement. It is one we should treasure. We should not allow it to be diminished through cynicism. Mr Speaker, I thank you for your role. I wish you and Penny all the very best for a a festive season. I extend the same wishes to the Deputy Speaker and to June-and to your colleagues who fill that important and honourable seat from time to time. Prime Minister, I thank you. Can I say to you that, as I think of your stewardship over the country and why people have chosen to extend that stewardship, your qualities come to mind-your personal courage, your tenacity. I think, Prime Minister, of your knowledge of, your understanding of and your commitment to the Australian people. I think that is now sensed deeply by the Australian people, but I suspect that even now they do not know the half of it. Your commitment to them is extraordinary. Your knowledge of their needs and your desire to see the interests of the country taken forward are remarkable. I salute you for that. I thank you for your decency in your dealings with me, my party and the people we try to represent. Can I say to you too, and I hope this does not sound presumptuous, that I count it a privilege to be able to term you a friend for the rest of my life. I thank my deputy leader, Mark Vaile. He has worked extraordinarily hard in the national interest this year. I salute him for it matters. and I acknowledge the sacrifices that he has made, particularly in his overseas schedules in pursuit of the American free trade agreement and so forth this year. And I thank Wendy-if I may be again presumptuousfor the sacrifices she has made in the national interest. I extend my thanks particularly to my own colleagues in The Nationals but obviously, in the context of this season, to all my colleagues in this place on both sides of the House. I would, understandably, like to particularly mention Larry Anthony and to say that we extend our best wishes to him and to Jenny. I do not think anyone would argue with the proposition that they poured their hearts and souls into that electorate and into this last election. The people spoke, and that is understood, respected and accepted, but it is a very sad thing for Larry, and we do wish him all the best over Christmas. I know that he was not alone in that disappointment, but I am sure members will understand why I single him out. I thank Andrew Hall, our federal director, and Helen Dickie, our federal president. Again, I want to say in relation to rural Australia-about which, of course, I am very passionate-that we ought not to have short memories. It is not so very long ago that there was enormous social dislocation out there. There were too many rural Australians who felt discontented and not respected for the role they play. Sometimes they were justified in that; sometimes they were not. But we have, in every way, through economic management and trying to work in partnership with local communities, sought to restore a degree of social cohesion. I think I can honestly say to this House that, as we go into this Christmas, there is a better mood across rural and regional Australia, a greater sense of hope and a greater sense that they are respected and valued-and I think that I believe very sincerely that social cohesion is a prerequisite for political stability, and political stability is very desirable in a nation like ours, not least of all-because of course it is very important-for economic progress. In that context, I again pay tribute to the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Peter Costello, who is a good friend and somebody whose counsel and advice I enjoy and interaction with whom I enjoy. I wish him and Tania, after a very long year, all the very best for their Christmas break. I acknowledge the Clerk, Mr Ian Harris, who helped me out this morning when I came rushing in here with bills that were not signed and what have you. I wish you and your staff all the best, and thank you for your work. The Australian Federal Police, a very respected body in this country who fulfil a very important role, deserve the accolades that have been showered upon them for their involvement in a number of causes here in Australia and, perhaps more particularly and especially, overseas in recent times. I also thank those who help in this House: the Hansard reporters, the attendants, and the people who work behind the scenes, as the Leader of the Opposition acknowledged-the cleaners and so forth. All of that is important work. That is the great foundation stone that is so important to the preservation of our freedoms in this country. We acknowledge the worth, the importance and the dignity of every individual and we thank them in the context of Christmas. I thank my personal staff, particularly my chief of staff, Peter Langhorne, and wish him, Marlene and their family all the very best. By extension, I ask that he carry on those best wishes to the rest of the team. I would certainly like to acknowledge in this place the love and support I have had from Julia. It is a tough and demanding proposition. In her case, she has kept the home fires burning with four young children, not quite so young anymore-it is amazing how quickly they grow. It is sometimes not quite understood just how difficult it can be to live out in the middle of an electorate that is the size of England and Scotland combined-the distances and the logistics of it all, trying to keep family together when there are no local schools, when getting to parliament and to the office let alone getting to the far-flung parts of the electorate and everyone else's electorate involves endless travel and endless logistical difficulties. So I thank her and record my appreciation and acknowledgment of the reality that I could not, of course, do without her. Christmas is a chance to spend time with our families and loved ones and to look beyond the events of the year to one that occurred a long time ago beneath a star and in a stable outside an inn. I am certainly very conscious that I do not deserve the title ‘Christian' in the sense that it is often taken to mean someone of virtue and decency. I do say though that I am a Christian believer, and in that context I am very conscious of my own failings, of the times when I am a hypocrite-freely pointed out in this place from time to time, I know. I just assure the Leader of the Opposition and his friends that I am usually aware of it before you point it out, often very uncomfortably so. In the context of my beliefs as a Christian, I am very conscious that the blood of the Cross means that I can personally be forgiven and, as I can be forgiven, there is an absolute responsibility on me to forgive others, to put the past behind and to move on. In the context of Christmas, a good healing exercise of putting those things behind us that are unnecessary and unfruitful to pursue is probably not a bad thing to ponder for a moment. So, in that context, to you, Mr Speaker, to all members of this House, to their families, to their loved ones, to their constituents, here and abroad, wherever they may be serving, wherever they may be living, I wish a happy, safe, holy, relaxed and refreshing Christmas.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: VALEDICTORY
text: Like most members in this House, I will be very pleased to get on my Christmas break and spend some time with family and friends. I am particularly looking forward to spending time with my family-my parents, John and Moira; my sister, Alison; and my niece and nephew, Tom and Jenna. I did have the opportunity to spend some time with my sister during the opening of parliament. She came it to the opening to meet the only truly famous person in the House of Representatives, Peter Garrett, and she succeeded in that task, but she also met the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition when she was here. It has been a long 12 months since we were at the dispatch box doing valedictories, and for some of us on the Labor side it was at the end of what was a pretty tumultuous week. In that set of valedictories, the Leader of the Opposition said about me: I think it is the first time we have had a numbers man and a numbers woman-the first time we have had two genders pitted against each in the roleof Leader of the House and Manager of Opposition Businessand I think it is a step forward for women in parliament to play a role outside of some of the stereotypes and expectations that we have heard in the past. I would like to thank the Leader of the Opposition for investing that faith in me then and for continuing that faith in me now. After what has been such a tough year for all of us, can I say that my faith in him is undiminished from that when we were last doing valedictories at this dispatch box. I wish him and Janine and the two boys a wonderful Christmas and some very well-deserved time off. I hope the opposition leader and his family have a great Christmas. In my role as Manager of Opposition Business I am obviously supported by the tactics committee. I thank my deputy manager, Anthony Albanese-better known to me as Albo over more than 20 years-for his support. I thank Jenny Macklin and Wayne Swan, and, of course, Simon Crean, who supports me still in the selection of House tactics but who has been such a great supporter of me in a number of other ways. I thank him for his continued investment of time and his continued assistance to me. Elections do bring changes. As the Leader of the Opposition has said, they have brought some changes in my office. I would particularly like to record my gratitude to Jamie Snashall, occasionally referred to by his friends as Sasha, as the Leader of the Opposition has saidMr Latham-By his friends.

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: VALEDICTORY
text: Yes. Jamie started with me as my one personal staff member when I first moved to the front bench after the 2001 election and we had the shadow portfolio of immigration. He stayed with me when we other had added to that the shadow portfolio of Indigenous affairs. He stayed with me when we had added to that Deputy Manager of Opposition Business. He stayed with me the when we then moved to health and he stayed with me when I had added to that the responsibility of Manager of Opposition Business. I would have to say that he has been to hell and back in three years in the service of the Labor Party. He has been a tremendous support to me and an incredibly hard working staff member. He is off to have a bit of a rest now, which he well deserves, but I know that he will be back in the service of the Labor Party and the labour movement very soon, and in a more senior role-certainly not one that has people screaming over his shoulder at five to two, ‘Where's the question time pack?' I also record my thanks to Ann Clark, who has moved from my office into the Leader of the Opposition's office. Ann travelled with me extensively last year, including 38 out of the 42 days in the election campaign. It was just her and me rattling around Australia, so it was a pretty big job. You have to get on when you spend that amount of time together. She is tremendous fun and a very great addition to the Leader of the Opposition's office. I record my thanks to Lesley Russell in my office, who works so hard on our health policy and is continuing to do so still. I record my thanks to my electorate office staff-Carlos, Fitzie and her sister Vicki, Rondah, Henry Barlow and John Ballestrino-for always looking after the electorate so well. I also record my thanks to the whips. You cannot do the Manager of Opposition Business job without the support of the whips, who play such a great role tactically and in other ways. My thanks go to Roger Price, Jill Hall and Michael Danby. Of course, I also record my thanks to Janice Crosio, who served in that very important job beforehand. I thank my colleagues, who are frequent sources of advice when it comes to tactical matters-things they think you did well and things they think you did pretty badly. They are pretty forthcoming. In that regard, my special thanks go to the members for Banks and Batman, who are always cheerfully prepared to comment on how things have gone and to give some suggestions about how they could or should have gone better. They have helped me a great deal. I thank the new members who have brought such energy and enthusiasm. They are not at the stage yet where they are making demands of the tactics committee, but I know that it will happen very soon. They will be there with their local issues, demanding a question. My thanks go to them for their new energy and enthusiasm. We will look forward to trying to hold them back from taking over question time next year. Mr Speaker, I thank you for working with us in the past two weeks. It has not been an easy start, as the Leader of the Opposition has said. I would like to record my thanks to Neil, of course. I will be in South Australia over the Christmas period and I have an open invitation to go and visit him. I may well do so when I am there. We look forward to working with you, Mr Speaker, in the coming year. I record my thanks to the clerks. One of the things you most do in opposition is rely on the clerks' advice. To the extent that we accidentally manage to get questions in order from time to time, that is normally the product of good advice that we have secured from the clerks. So I thank Ian and Bernie for their assistance, which is very important to us. I thank Judy Middlebrook and the chamber research staff, on whom we are all so very reliant. I thank Gerard, the Parliamentary Liaison Officer and his staff. We are very reliant on them in opposition. I thank them very much. I thank all of the remaining staff at Parliament House, who make the building work so well-the Comcar drivers, the security, the attendants, the cleaners, the catering staff and everybody else. I record my very deep personal thanks to Aussies. It is only their coffee that makes the difference between living and dying on some days. I thank them very much for the contribution they make. I wish the Leader of the House, the Minister for Health and Ageing, Tony Abbott, the compliments of the season and a good break over Christmas. I have been joking with him that we need to negotiate ceasefire dates so that we can both have a restful Christmas. I think there is some merit in that. I wish the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Treasurer and members of the government generally a good Christmas break, as I do all of the colleagues on my side of the House. We look forward to being back in this place, once again joined in combat over the dispatch box, in the new year.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: VALEDICTORY
text: I join with other members who have already spoken. Christmas, of course, commemorates the birth of Christ, and the message is: peace on earth and goodwill toward men and women. I extend my goodwill to all of my wonderful colleagues and the members of the opposition, and particularly to the colleagues who have joined us as a consequence of the most recent election. It gives you enormous new enthusiasm and freshness to see people come into this place who look at it with new eyes and give you new perspectives. Those of us who have been here for a while probably have come to see the parliament through our own perspective and experiences. All of a sudden, new eyes give you new insights and freshness. I also want to thank and congratulate each and every one of those new members that have come here to join us. I think it is important that we approach our task with a sense of humour every now and then. I try and amuse myself at the dispatch box and sometimes manage to amuse some other people as well. Honestly, it is a terrible job, but someone has to do it. It would be a dull old place if we did not manage to amuse ourselves and keep our interest. The day we lose our humour about what we do is the day that the parliament and the nation will be worse off. I say, not at all in a partisan spirit, that go into Christmas with more Australians in work than ever before in our history and with unemployment lower than it has been in 27 years. I think that is something that will make it a better Christmas for many more Australians. Nothing destroys a family like unemployment and nothing destroys selfconfidence like unemployment. I just hope that those who have found work can keep it and those who are looking for work can find it. I regard that as one of the most important tasks that we have as members of parliament. We remember those Australians serving overseas in our defence forces at the moment and we value their work. We have Treasury officials at the moment in PNG and the Solomons. I pay tribute to them for the work they are doing in reconstruction. I thank the Secretary of the Treasury, Ken Henry, and the department for the work they do and the contribution they make, which I think in international terms would make them certainly one of the most professional outfits anywhere around the world. I would like to pay tribute to the Prime Minister for leading the coalition to his fourth election victory. This is an extraordinary performance, on our side of the parliament matched only by the great man, Sir Robert Menzies, who founded our party and led us to more victories. I think on the Labor side it is matched only by Bob Hawke. So that just puts the Prime Minister in a new class of political leader. I extend my congratulations to him, to Janette and to his family; to John Anderson and his wife, JuliaJohn is one of nature's gentlemen and somebody who shows great Christian character; to Mark Vaile and his wife, Wendy; and to our Senate team. I particularly thank my Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Revenue, Mal Brough, and his wife, Sue. It is not easy running a revenue system. Australians are very we simple in what they want from their politicians. They want them to collect less tax and they want them to spend more money. It is because those two propositions are incompatible that politics exists. If we were able to spend more money and take less tax, then the business of politics would not exist. It is the irresistible force meeting the immovable object that gives rise to the profession of politics. If you are running the revenue system it does not qualify you for sainthood or popularity amongst your colleagues. I pay tribute to Mal for his work and to Chris Pearce, my parliamentary secretary, for his assistance. Tony Abbott, the Leader of the House, is one of nature's misunderstood men, a true gentleman and a soft man at heart, who is often misunderstood. People think that Tony is hard, but to deal with him is to melt in his hands. Mr Speaker, I congratulate you for the recognition that you deserve and for your elevation to the great role of Speaker. To you and to Penny I want to wish a very happy and restful Christmas. Ian Harris and Bernard Wright are public servants in the greatest tradition. What I admire is that you advise each side to the best of your ability and never allow personal views to intrude. Whether you are sitting on this side or on the other side, the advice that you give is flawless. Please thank all of the people that work for you, and I thank you for the work that you do. To my own staff, led by Phil Gaetjens, chief of staff, and Lizzie MCCabe, who is one of the best people you will ever come across, I want to thank you. I thank each and every one of them. Our federal director, Brian Loughnane, now has a flawless federal strike record-one-zip. Julian Sheezel, our state director, and Helen Kroger, our state president, who have done a fantastic job, I want to thank you as well. We all indulge ourselves in politics, but it is our families that bear a lot of the brunt. I want to thank my wife, Tanya, my son, Sebastian, and my daughters, Madeleine and Phoebe, who have put up with quite a lot this year. It is particularly hard I think on the mothers, who essentially become single mothers. Whilst we have a little bit more of the fun in the parliament, they are minding the home front. I think it is extraordinarily difficult and I pay tribute to my own family and thank them very deeply for the sacrifices that they have made. Still, this is the greatest honour that any person could have: to be able to stand in the House of Representatives, to represent people in Australia, to minister of the Crown, to be entrusted with the ability to make decisions which will shape a nation. This is a great honour and a great privilege. Like many members here, I feel awed by it. I thank the electors and the people of Australia for the trust that they place in us, for our colleagues that share that trust and for our nation, which I hope will go on to continuing strength in the year ahead.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: VALEDICTORY
text: Very briefly, because much has been said and does not need to be repeated, I wish to pay particular tribute to the clerks, the guardians of the traditions of this place, and to the parliamentary liaison staff, particularly Gerard Martin and his team. The member for Lalor and I have had, I think, a perfectly cordial relationship outside this chamber, if not necessarily inside this chamber, and I thank her for her constructive work in the smooth management of the House. While I am acknowledging and thanking you and congratulating you, Mr Speaker, it is probably appropriate to acknowledge your predecessor. Neil Andrew occupied the chair with distinction and with personal dignity. He was often put upon, but he never lost his cool, and that is to his credit. I probably should also acknowledge a couple of dear friends who are no longer with us-they are with us in life but not in this parliament-David Kemp, a mentor of mine in the Fightback era; Trish Worth, a former parliamentary secretary and a real fighter, particularly on mental health issues and drug safety; and also someone who left the parliament under difficult circumstances, the former member for Parramatta, Ross Cameron. Ross had his faults, but he was a great contributor. I think that the tone of this House was certainly lifted by him. I thank my staff, particularly Paris Kostakos. None of us can do anything effectively without be a help. She is my parliamentary adviser and does a great job, and it helps not just the parliament but many people here. Finally, as has been acknowledged, I thank all of our families. They are the conscripts in politics. They have a hard life because of us and they should be remembered now. As Peter Costello and others have said, we are very privileged to be here. The challenge is to be worthy of the privilege that we have been given. May God bless us in this Christmas season and may God help us in the year ahead, because Lord knows we will need it.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: VALEDICTORY
text: First of all I would like to thank all those who have already spoken for their kind words to me as the Speaker-the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Manager of Opposition Business, the Treasurer and the Leader of the House-and also to join with them in thanking those who have worked so hard, so professionally and often unseen in supporting the smooth running of this chamber. Previous Speakers have admitted the difficulty in trying to select a few from the list of so many who contribute in so many ways to the day-today running of the parliament. I find myself in that same predicament and I apologise in advance to those whom I may inadvertently overlook. But I would like to mention in particular the Deputy Speaker, the member for Page, Ian Causley; the Second Deputy Speaker, the member for Scullin, Harry Jenkins; and the members of the Speaker's panel-all of whom have, I think, done an outstanding job in both this parliament and the last parliament. I would also like to mention the Clerk, Ian Harris, and the Deputy Clerk, Bernard Wright, for their very impartial professional advice, which is so important, as has already been said, particularly for a new Speaker. I mention too the clerks assistant, Robyn MCClelland and Robyn Webber, and Laraine Brennan. I also mention the Serjeant-atArms, David Elder, the Deputy Serjeant, Claressa Surtees, Dalma Dixon, Barry Gwyther and the staff at the Serjeant's office. I mention Peter Mason and the staff at the Table Office; Judy Middlebrook and the staff of the chamber research office; committee secretaries and staff; other staff of the Department of the House of Representatives; Chris Paterson and the staff of the Parliamentary Relations Office; the Parliamentary Education Office; the messagerial attendants and security staff; the expert and patient people who staff the 2020 help desk; the staff of the first aid centre; the car drivers; the guides; the gardeners; the Hyatt; the cleaners; Aussie's; the florist; Synergy; Lizzie; Westpac; Auspic; and many others. But I particular want to pay tribute to the dedication, commitment and professionalism of Hilary Penfold, the Secretary of the new Department of Parliamentary Services, and her staff. There have been enormous difficulties and challenges associated with the restructuring of the administration of the parliament and the amalgamation of the three service departments into one. This has proved far more successful than could have been hoped or envisaged when the new department was established 12 months ago. As usual, the excellent standard of assistance, advice and facilities provided by the staff of the information and research services group and the resource management services group-which includes the library-the client services group, the security and facilities group and the corporate and strategic development group ensure that the services provided to our members of parliament are among the best in the world. At Parliament House we are very much a family. Some members of it deserve a special mention. I just want to mention two. Monika Velten is leaving after 23 years service in the cafeterias of both Old Parliament House and new Parliament House. I think her cheerful and friendly service has been much appreciated and will be greatly missed. Marie Donnelly recently retired after almost 30 years service in the Speaker's office. Marie, who has served every Speaker since she joined the department in 1975, was held in great affection and esteem by everyone and will be a very hard act to follow. We only hope she does not carry out her threat to write a book of her experiences with all the material she has collected! Also retiring from extended service to parliament and the Speaker's office is Pauline Osmond. Many will know that Pauline came to parliament to assist Bob Halverson when he was elected as member for Casey in 1984. She went with Bob to the Speaker's office in 1996 and provided outstanding support to my predecessor, Neil Andrew, and then to me since I have become the Speaker. Her advice has always been astute and her contribution excellent, and most importantly her sense of humour, friendship and high spirits have always been essential in the bonding of a very hard working team. I certainly wish her well. Best wishes for a speedy return to health go to Andy Hall, one of the people who represent so well the dedication and loyalty often unseen and unheralded from the staff of the Department of the House of Representatives. They make our lives liveable by so willingly and efficiently providing us with the services and support that are necessary for us to undertake our services as members of the parliament. I think we should recognise the efforts of all in that respect. Best wishes also go to former Clerk Lyn Barlin, who is thankfully on the mend after having an argument with a trailer-which unfortunately the trailer won. But he is on the mend. I would also like to add my special thanks to my predecessor Neil Andrew. Although Neil did speak to me after I became the Speaker, I do not think there is any way that he could prepare me for the challenges that have come with this complex job. I certainly recognise and commend him for the distinction with which he served in this office for six years. As mentioned earlier, a sad note today is the loss of Alan Browning, a former Clerk of the House. He made a contribution to the parliament over 36 years, including over six years as Clerk. Our thoughts are with his family at this time. I would also like to thank my electorate office, and particularly Megan Campbell, who has been with me now for almost 17 years. She is a very loyal, efficient and dedicated member of my team, together with Jane Macdonald and Lizzie Haskell. I send my best wishes to the staff of the Speaker's office, especially Peter Gibson, who is senior adviser and chief of staff and who has an amazing knowledge and understanding of this institution. His good judgment and objective, unbiased advice has managed to get me through my first few weeks as the Speaker. Thanks also go to Barbara Williams, who keeps me organised, and Yvonne Bailey, who after some years serving as a Speaker's attendant is now learning the ropes in the very important role that Marie Donnelly had. I would also like to thank Sarah MCArthur, Stewart's daughter, who has worked as a volunteer in my office over the past few weeks-and I do not think she will ever want to see a Christmas card again. Finally I want to thank my wife, Penny, and our children, Peter, Melissa, Richard and James, who are my greatest and most fearless supporters. I do not think many people other than those who are in this chamber realise or appreciate just how demanding being a member of parliament is and also how very valuable support from families is. I am sure that you would appreciate that, when you become Speaker, that support is doubly appreciated. As usual, Penny and my family have stood beside me at every step as I go through parliament, and I certainly count their love and support as one of the very special parts of my life. We have come to the end of 2004 and, as has been said, it has been a very demanding year. No doubt 2005 in its own way will be a very demanding year. I too would like to extend to everyone my very best wishes for a healthy, happy, safe and peaceful Christmas and, hopefully, a very good New Year. I certainly look forward to catching up again with everyone when the parliament resumes in February.
